title: 114_hr2357
content:
The "Accelerating Access to Capital Act of 2016" allows expanded eligibility for the use of Form S-3 by the Securities and Exchange Commission, removing certain requirements and providing exemptions for micro-offerings. The "Accelerating Access to Capital Act of 2016" expands Form S-3 eligibility by the SEC, removing requirements and exemptions for micro-offerings involving limited purchasers with pre-existing relationships with the issuer. The exemption under subsection (a)(8) allows for the sale of securities to no more than 35 purchasers within a 12-month period, with an aggregate amount not exceeding $500,000. Disqualification applies if any person triggering disqualification under section 230.506(d) of title 17, Code of Federal Regulations is involved in the transaction. The individuals covered under this subparagraph include the issuer, any predecessors or affiliated issuers, directors, executive officers, beneficial owners of 20% or more of voting equity securities, promoters, investment managers of pooled investment funds, and persons receiving remuneration for soliciting purchasers. The Securities Act of 1933 is amended to include exemptions under state regulations, specifically adding section 4(a)(8) as a new exemption. This applies to various individuals involved in the offering of investment managers or solicitors, including general partners, managing members, directors, executive officers, and other officers. TITLE III--PRIVATE PLACEMENT IMPROVEMENT

SEC. 301. REVISIONS TO SEC REGULATION D. The Securities and Exchange Commission will revise Regulation D within 45 days of the enactment of the Act. The revisions include requiring issuers to file a single notice of sales for each new offering of securities under Rule 506, making Form D filings available to state securities commissions, and not conditioning availability on any requirements. The Securities and Exchange Commission will revise Regulation D within 45 days of the Act's enactment. The revisions include not conditioning the availability of exemptions for issuers under Rule 506 on filing Form D, not requiring written general solicitation materials for Rule 506(c) offerings, not extending Rule 156 requirements to private funds, and revising Rule 501(a) to include knowledgeable employees as accredited. Rule 3c-5(a)(4) states that a knowledgeable employee can be considered an accredited investor for a Rule 506 offering of a private fund. The House of Representatives passed the document on September 8, 2016, with Karen L. Haas as the Clerk.
